content.value_statement: Access RCSB PDB for 3D protein/nucleic acid structures. Search by text/sequence/structure, download coordinates (PDB/mmCIF), retrieve metadata, for structural biology and drug discovery.
actual_capabilities: Search for protein and nucleic acid 3D structures by text, keywords, or descriptions
Query structures by attributes including organism, resolution, and experimental method
Find structurally similar entries using sequence and 3D geometry similarity searches
Retrieve detailed structure metadata including experimental conditions and quality metrics
Download coordinate files in PDB, mmCIF, and BinaryCIF formats
Parse and analyze structure coordinates using BioPython or similar libraries
Perform batch operations across multiple protein structures
Access the RCSB GraphQL API for flexible custom queries
limitations: Requires active network connection to RCSB PDB APIs
API rate limits apply to search and download requests
Some older structures may have incomplete or legacy metadata
Large structure downloads may take significant time
BinaryCIF format requires additional library setup for parsing
Computed models (AlphaFold, RoseTTAFold) have limited experimental validation

use_cases.title: Drug Discovery Research
use_cases.description: Search for structures of drug targets, analyze ligand binding sites, and compare protein-ligand complexes to identify similar binding pockets for virtual screening.
use_cases.target_user: Computational chemists and drug discovery researchers

use_cases.title: Protein Engineering Analysis
use_cases.description: Find homologous structures for homology modeling, analyze sequence-structure relationships, and compare mutant structures to study protein stability.

use_cases.title: Structural Biology Research
use_cases.description: Download structures for computational analysis, build structure-based alignments, and compare experimental methods and quality metrics across entries.
use_cases.target_user: Academic researchers and students in structural biology

use_cases.title: Educational Molecular Visualization
use_cases.description: Retrieve structures for teaching molecular biology concepts, generate visualizations, and explore structure-function relationships interactively.
use_cases.target_user: Educators and students in life sciences

prompt_templates.title: Search Protein Structure by Name
prompt_templates.prompt: Find PDB entries for the protein [PROTEIN_NAME]. How many structures are available? What is the resolution range?
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user wants to find available 3D structures for a specific protein

prompt_templates.title: Download Structure Coordinates
prompt_templates.prompt: Download the [PDB_ID] structure in mmCIF format and tell me the experimental method used and the resolution.
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user needs to download a specific structure file with metadata

prompt_templates.title: Find Similar Structures
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all human protein structures with resolution better than 2.0 Ã… that contain a ligand.
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user needs structures meeting specific quality and content criteria

prompt_templates.title: Batch Retrieve Multiple Structures
prompt_templates.prompt: Get the titles, resolution, and deposition dates for structures [PDB_ID_1], [PDB_ID_2], and [PDB_ID_3].
prompt_templates.scenario: When a user needs metadata for multiple specific structures

output_examples.input: Search for hemoglobin structures from Homo sapiens
output: Found 1,847 structures for hemoglobin from Homo sapiens:
3. 2HHB - Hemoglobin C (2.6 Ã… resolution, X-ray diffraction)
Most structures are determined by X-ray crystallography with resolutions ranging from 1.5 Ã… to 3.5 Ã….
Successfully downloaded 1MBN.cif (Myoglobin, 2.0 Ã… resolution, X-ray diffraction)

best_practices: Always handle API errors gracefully with try-except blocks for production workflows
Cache frequently accessed structure data to reduce redundant API calls
Use the most specific query possible to minimize result set size
Combine multiple query types with logical operators for precise searches
Check resolution and experimental method when evaluating structure quality
Respect API rate limits by adding delays between batch requests
Use mmCIF format for large complexes as it handles large structures better than legacy PDB format
anti_patterns: Making thousands of rapid API requests without implementing rate limiting
Skipping error handling when fetching multiple structures in a loop
Using legacy PDB format for large complexes that exceed format limitations
Assuming all structures have complete metadata (older entries may be sparse)
Not validating PDB IDs before attempting downloads
Ignoring resolution when selecting structures for molecular modeling

faq.question: What file formats are supported for downloading structures?
faq.answer: The RCSB PDB supports three main formats: PDB (legacy text format, limited to 999,999 atoms), mmCIF (modern standard format, handles large structures), and BinaryCIF (compressed binary format, most efficient for large structures). For most applications, mmCIF is recommended as it supports all structure sizes and is the official archive format.

faq.question: What is the difference between experimentally determined and computed model structures?
faq.answer: Experimentally determined structures (the majority in PDB) are derived from methods like X-ray crystallography, NMR spectroscopy, or cryo-EM, and represent actual measurements. Computed models (from AlphaFold, RoseTTAFold, etc.) are predictions based on protein sequence, indicated by PDB IDs starting with 'AF_' or 'MA_'. Computed models have high completeness but lack experimental validation.

faq.question: Are there rate limits for the RCSB PDB API?
faq.answer: Yes, the RCSB PDB enforces rate limits to ensure service availability. For high-volume queries, implement delays of 0.5-1 second between requests. For bulk downloads, consider using their dedicated download server rather than the REST API. Commercial applications may require special licensing arrangements.

faq.question: How do I find structures for a specific organism?
faq.answer: Use the AttributeQuery with the rcsb_entity_source_organism.scientific_name attribute. For example, query for 'Homo sapiens' to find human structures. You can also filter by taxonomy ID using rcsb_entity_src_nat_tax_id when more precise organism matching is needed.

faq.question: What does resolution mean and why is it important?
faq.answer: Resolution (measured in Angstroms, Ã…) indicates the level of detail in crystallographic structures. Lower values mean higher detail: sub-2.0 Ã… is excellent, 2.0-2.5 Ã… is good, and 3.0+ Ã… shows less atomic detail. Resolution affects the reliability of structural interpretations, particularly for ligand binding sites and side chain positions.
